entities.description: Morgan Frederick Rielly is a Canadian professional ice hockey defenceman and alternate captain of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League (NHL). He was drafted by the Maple Leafs in the first round, fifth overall, of the 2012 NHL Entry Draft. Before being drafted, Rielly played with the Moose Jaw Warriors of the Western Hockey League. He has represented Canada internationally on seve

heading: Deaths
txt: Abu Ma'shar al-Balkhi, Muslim scholar and astrologer (b. 787)

entities.title: Abu Ma'shar al-Balkhi
entities.description: Abu Ma'shar, Latinized as Albumasar, was an early Persian Muslim astrologer, thought to be the greatest astrologer of the Abbasid court in Baghdad. While he was not a major innovator, his practical manuals for training astrologers profoundly influenced Muslim intellectual history and, through translations, that of western Europe and Byzantium.

entities.title: Astrology in medieval Islam
entities.description: Some medieval Muslims took a keen interest in the study of astrology, despite the Islamic prohibitions: partly because they considered the celestial bodies to be essential, partly because the dwellers of desert-regions often travelled at night, and relied upon knowledge of the constellations for guidance in their journeys. After the advent of Islam, the Muslims needed to determine the time of the

heading: Deaths
txt: Sverre of Norway

entities.title: Sverre of Norway
entities.description: Sverre Sigurdsson was the King of Norway from 1184 to 1202.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frances of Rome, Italian nun and saint (b. 1384)

entities.title: Frances of Rome
entities.description: Frances of Rome, Obl.S.B., is an Italian saint who was a wife, mother, mystic, organizer of charitable services and a Benedictine oblate who founded a religious community of oblates, who share a common life without religious vows.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonardo Bruni, Italian humanist (b. c.1370)

entities.title: Leonardo Bruni
entities.description: Leonardo Bruni was an Italian humanist, historian and statesman, often recognized as the most important humanist historian of the early Renaissance. He has been called the first modern historian. He was the earliest person to write using the three-period view of history: Antiquity, Middle Ages, and Modern. The dates Bruni used to define the periods are not exactly what modern historians use today,

heading: Deaths
txt: Catherine of Bologna, Italian nun and saint (d. 1463)

entities.title: Catherine of Bologna
entities.description: Catherine of Bologna [Caterina de' Vigri] was an Italian Poor Clare nun, writer, teacher, mystic, artist, and saint. The patron saint of artists and against temptations, Catherine de' Vigri was venerated for nearly three centuries in her native Bologna before being formally canonized in 1712. Her feast day is 9 March.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Rizzio, Italian-Scottish courtier and politician (b. 1533).

entities.title: David Rizzio
entities.description: David Rizzio, sometimes written as David Riccio, was an Italian courtier, born close to Turin, a descendant of an ancient and noble family still living in Piedmont, the Riccio Counts di San Paolo e Solbrito, who rose to become the private secretary of Mary, Queen of Scots. Mary's husband, Lord Darnley, is said to have been jealous of their friendship because of rumours that Rizzio had impregnated

heading: Deaths
txt: James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Hamilton, Scottish soldier and politician, (b. 1606)

entities.title: James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Hamilton
entities.description: James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Hamilton, KG, PC, known as The 3rd Marquess of Hamilton from March 1625 until April 1643, was a Scottish nobleman and influential political and military leader during the Thirty Years' War and the Wars of the Three Kingdoms.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Rich, 1st Earl of Holland, English soldier and politician (b. 1590)

heading: Deaths
txt: Cardinal Mazarin, Italian-French academic and politician, Prime Minister of France (b. 1602)

entities.title: Cardinal Mazarin
entities.description: Cardinal Jules Mazarin, born Giulio Raimondo Mazzarino or Mazarini, was an Italian cardinal, diplomat, and politician who served as the chief minister to the kings of France Louis XIII and Louis XIV from 1642 until his death in 1661. In 1654 he acquired the title Duke of Mayenne, and in 1659, 1st Duke of Rethel and Nevers.

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

heading: Deaths
txt: Ralph Montagu, 1st Duke of Montagu, English courtier and politician (b. 1638)

entities.title: Ralph Montagu, 1st Duke of Montagu
entities.description: Ralph Montagu, 1st Duke of Montagu was an English courtier and diplomat.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Bonomi the Elder, Italian architect (b. 1739)

entities.title: Joseph Bonomi the Elder
entities.description: Joseph Bonomi the Elder was an Italian architect and draughtsman who spent most of his career in England where he became a successful designer of country houses.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ozias Humphry, English painter and academic (b. 1742)

entities.title: Ozias Humphry
entities.description: Ozias Humphry was a leading English painter of portrait miniatures, later oils and pastels, of the 18th century. He was elected to the Royal Academy in 1791, and in 1792 he was appointed Portrait Painter in Crayons to the King.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna Laetitia Barbauld, English poet, author, and critic (b. 1743)

entities.title: Anna Laetitia Barbauld
entities.description: Anna Laetitia Barbauld was a prominent English poet, essayist, literary critic, editor, and author of children's literature. A "woman of letters" who published in multiple genres, Barbauld had a successful writing career at a time when women rarely wrote professionally.

heading: Deaths
txt: Friedrich Maximilian von Klinger, German author and playwright (b. 1752)

entities.title: Friedrich Maximilian von Klinger
entities.description: Friedrich Maximilian von Klinger was a German dramatist and novelist. His play Sturm und Drang (1776) gave its name to the Sturm und Drang artistic epoch. He was a childhood friend of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and is often closely associated with Jakob Michael Reinhold Lenz. Klinger worked as a playwright for the Seylersche Schauspiel-Gesellschaft for two years, but eventually left the Kingdom of

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Anning, English paleontologist (b. 1799)

entities.title: Mary Anning
entities.description: Mary Anning was an English fossil collector, dealer, and palaeontologist who became known around the world for finds she made in Jurassic marine fossil beds in the cliffs along the English Channel at Lyme Regis in the county of Dorset in Southwest England. Anning's findings contributed to changes in scientific thinking about prehistoric life and the history of the Earth.

entities.title: Paleontology
entities.description: Paleontology, also spelled palaeontology or palæontology, is the scientific study of life that existed prior to, and sometimes including, the start of the Holocene Epoch. It includes the study of fossils to classify organisms and study interactions with each other and their environments. Paleontological observations have been documented as far back as the 5th century BCE. The science became establ

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans Christian Ørsted, Danish physicist and chemist (b. 1777)

entities.title: Hans Christian Ørsted
entities.description: Hans Christian Ørsted was a Danish physicist and chemist who discovered that electric currents create magnetic fields, which was the first connection found between electricity and magnetism. Oersted's law and the oersted (Oe) are named after him.

heading: Deaths
txt: William I, German Emperor (b. 1797)

entities.title: William I, German Emperor
entities.description: William I or Wilhelm I of the House of Hohenzollern was King of Prussia from 2 January 1861 and the first German emperor from 18 January 1871 until his death. William was the first head of state of a united Germany, and was also de facto head of state of Prussia from 1858 to 1861, serving as regent for his brother, Frederick William IV.

heading: Deaths
txt: Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, Austrian journalist and author (b. 1836)

entities.title: Leopold von Sacher-Masoch
entities.description: Leopold Ritter von Sacher-Masoch was an Austrian nobleman, writer and journalist, who gained renown for his romantic stories of Galician life. The term masochism is derived from his name, invented by his contemporary, the Austrian psychiatrist Richard von Krafft-Ebing. Masoch did not approve of this use of his name.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sondre Norheim, Norwegian-American skier (b. 1825)

entities.title: Sondre Norheim
entities.description: Sondre Norheim, born Sondre Auverson, was a Norwegian skier and pioneer of modern skiing. Sondre Norheim is known as the father of Telemark skiing.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Wedekind, German author and playwright (b. 1864)

entities.title: Frank Wedekind
entities.description: Benjamin Franklin Wedekind, usually known as Frank Wedekind, was a German playwright. His work, which often criticizes bourgeois attitudes, is considered to anticipate expressionism and was influential in the development of epic theatre.

heading: Deaths
txt: Willard Metcalf, American painter and academic (b. 1858)

entities.title: Willard Metcalf
entities.description: Willard Leroy Metcalf was an American artist born in Lowell, Massachusetts. He studied at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and later attended Académie Julian, Paris. After early figure-painting and illustration, he became prominent as a landscape painter. He was one of the Ten American Painters who in 1897 seceded from the Society of American Artists. For some years he was an instruc

heading: Deaths
txt: Mikao Usui, Japanese spiritual leader, founded Reiki (b. 1865)

entities.title: Mikao Usui
entities.description: Mikao Usui was the promoter of a form of spiritual practice known as Reiki, used as an alternative therapy for the treatment of physical, emotional, and mental diseases. According to the inscription on his memorial stone, Usui taught Reiki to over 2,000 people during his lifetime. Eleven of these students continued their training to reach the Shinpiden level, a level equivalent to the Western thir

entities.title: Reiki
entities.description: Reiki  is a Japanese form of alternative medicine called energy healing. Reiki practitioners use a technique called palm healing or hands-on healing through which a "universal energy" is said to be transferred through the palms of the practitioner to the patient in order to encourage emotional or physical healing.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Elmer More, American journalist and critic (b. 1864)

entities.title: Paul Elmer More
entities.description: Paul Elmer More was an American journalist, critic, essayist and Christian apologist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Freundlich, German painter and sculptor (b. 1878)

entities.title: Otto Freundlich
entities.description: Otto Freundlich was a German painter and sculptor of Jewish origin. A part of the first generation of abstract painters in Western art, Freundlich was a great admirer of cubism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vagn Walfrid Ekman, Swedish oceanographer and academic (b. 1874)

entities.title: Vagn Walfrid Ekman
entities.description: Vagn Walfrid Ekman was a Swedish oceanographer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Miroslava, Czech-Mexican actress (b. 1925)

entities.title: Miroslava (actress)
entities.description: Miroslava Šternová, better known as Miroslava, was a Czechoslovak-born Mexican film actress who appeared in thirty two films.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck, German general (b. 1870)

entities.title: Paul von Lettow-Vorbeck
entities.description: Paul Emil von Lettow-Vorbeck, also called the Lion of Africa, was a general in the Imperial German Army and the commander of its forces in the German East Africa campaign. For four years, with a force of about 14,000, he held in check a much larger force of 300,000 British, Indian, Belgian, and Portuguese troops.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abdul Munim Riad, Egyptian general (b. 1919)

entities.title: Abdul Munim Riad
entities.description: Abdul Munim Riad was a general and chief of staff of the Egyptian Armed Forces. Riad commanded the Jordanian forces in the 1967 Six-Day War and later commanded Egyptian forces in the War of Attrition, during which he was killed along with several of his aides in 1969.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Cyril VI of Alexandria (b. 1902)

entities.title: Pope Cyril VI of Alexandria
entities.description: This article uses dates and years written in the Coptic calendar, using the A.M. calendar era, in addition to the Gregorian calendar, using the A.D. calendar era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Earl Wilbur Sutherland, Jr., American pharmacologist and biochemist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1915)

entities.title: Earl Wilbur Sutherland, Jr.
entities.description: Earl Wilbur Sutherland Jr. was an American pharmacologist and biochemist born in Burlingame, Kansas. Sutherland won a Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1971 "for his discoveries concerning the mechanisms of the action of hormones", especially epinephrine, via second messengers, namely cyclic adenosine monophosphate, or cyclic AMP.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Womack, American singer (b. 1945)

heading: Deaths
txt: Faye Emerson, American actress (b. 1917)

entities.title: Faye Emerson
entities.description: Faye Margaret Emerson was an American film and stage actress and television interviewer who gained fame as a film actress in the 1940s before transitioning to television in the 1950s and hosting her own talk show.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ulf von Euler, Swedish physiologist and pharmacologist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1905)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kurt Georg Kiesinger, German lawyer, politician and Chancellor of Germany (b. 1904)

entities.title: Kurt Georg Kiesinger
entities.description: Kurt Georg Kiesinger was a German politician who served as Chancellor of Germany from 1 December 1966 to 21 October 1969. Before he became Chancellor he was a Nazi Party member, served as Minister President of Baden-Württemberg from 1958 to 1966 and as President of the Federal Council from 1962 to 1963. He was Chairman of the Christian Democratic Union from 1967 to 1971.

entities.title: Chancellor of Germany
entities.description: The chancellor of Germany, officially the federal chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is the head of government and chief executive of Germany, as well as the commander in chief of the German Armed Forces during wartime. The chancellor is elected by the Bundestag on the proposal of the federal president and without debate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Mapplethorpe, American photographer (b. 1946)

entities.title: Robert Mapplethorpe
entities.description: Robert Michael Mapplethorpe was an American photographer, best known for his black-and-white photographs. His work featured an array of subjects, including celebrity portraits, male and female nudes, self-portraits, and still-life images. His most controversial works documented and examined the gay male BDSM subculture of New York City in the late 1960s and early 1970s. A 1989 exhibition of Mapple

heading: Deaths
txt: Jim Hardin, American baseball player (b. 1943)

entities.title: Jim Hardin
entities.description: James Warren Hardin was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as a right-handed pitcher from 1967 through 1972, most notably as a member of the Baltimore Orioles dynasty that won three consecutive American League pennants from 1969 to 1971 and, won the World Series in 1970. He also played for the New York Yankees and the Atlanta Braves.

heading: Deaths
txt: Menachem Begin, Belarusian-Israeli soldier, politician and Prime Minister of Israel, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1913)

entities.title: Menachem Begin
entities.description: Menachem Begin was an Israeli politician, founder of Likud and the sixth Prime Minister of Israel. Before the creation of the state of Israel, he was the leader of the Zionist militant group Irgun, the Revisionist breakaway from the larger Jewish paramilitary organization Haganah. He proclaimed a revolt, on 1 February 1944, against the British mandatory government, which was opposed by the Jewish

entities.title: Prime Minister of Israel
entities.description: The prime minister of Israel is the head of government and chief executive of Israel.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: C. Northcote Parkinson, English historian and author (b. 1909)

entities.title: C. Northcote Parkinson
entities.description: Cyril Northcote Parkinson was a British naval historian and author of some 60 books, the most famous of which was his best-seller Parkinson's Law (1957), in which Parkinson advanced Parkinson's law, stating that "work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion", an insight which led him to be regarded as an important scholar in public administration and management.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Bukowski, American poet, novelist, and short story writer (b. 1920)

entities.title: Charles Bukowski
entities.description: Henry Charles Bukowski was a German–American poet, novelist, and short story writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eddie Creatchman, Canadian wrestler, referee, and manager (b. 1928)

heading: Deaths
txt: Fernando Rey, Spanish actor (b. 1917)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Dominique Bauby, French journalist and author (b. 1952)

entities.title: Jean-Dominique Bauby
entities.description: Jean-Dominique Bauby was a French journalist, author and editor of the French fashion magazine Elle. He had two children with Sylvie de la Rochefoucauld: a son named Théophile and a daughter named Céleste.

heading: Deaths
txt: Terry Nation, Welsh author and screenwriter (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: The Notorious B.I.G., American rapper, songwriter, and actor (b. 1972)

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Somers, Canadian pianist and composer (b. 1925)

entities.title: Harry Somers
entities.description:
Harry Stewart Somers, CC was one of the most influential and innovative contemporary Canadian composers of the past century. Possessing a charismatic attitude and rather dashing good-looks, as well as a genuine talent for his art, Somers earned the unofficial title of "Darling of Canadian Composition." 
A truly patriotic artist, Somers was engaged in many national projects over the course his life

heading: Deaths
txt: George Singh, Belizean jurist and Chief Justice of Belize (b. 1937)

entities.title: Chief Justice of Belize
entities.description: The Chief Justice of Belize is the head of the Supreme Court of Belize. Under Chapter 7 of the Constitution of Belize, the Chief Justice is appointed by the Governor-General on the advice of the Prime Minister.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Coulthard, Canadian composer and educator (b. 1908)

entities.title: Jean Coulthard
entities.description: Jean Coulthard, was a Canadian composer and music educator. She was one of a trio of women composers who dominated Western Canadian music in the twentieth century: Coulthard, Barbara Pentland, and Violet Archer. All three died within weeks of each other in 2000. Her own work might be loosely termed "prematurely neo-Romantic", as the orthodox serialists who dominated academic musical life in North

heading: Deaths
txt: Stan Brakhage, American director and cinematographer (b. 1933)

entities.title: Stan Brakhage
entities.description: James Stanley Brakhage, better known as Stan Brakhage, was an American filmmaker. He is considered to be one of the most important figures in 20th-century experimental film.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard Dowiyogo, Nauruan politician, President of Nauru (b. 1946)

entities.title: President of Nauru
entities.description: The President of Nauru is elected by Parliament from among its members, and is both the head of state and the head of government of Nauru. Nauru's unicameral Parliament has 19 members, with an electoral term of 3 years. Political parties only play a minor role in Nauru politics, and there have often been periods of instability in the Presidential office. Shifting allegiances among a small number o

heading: Deaths
txt: John Mayer, Indian composer (b. 1930)

entities.title: John Mayer (composer)
entities.description: John Mayer was an Indian composer known primarily for his fusions of jazz with Indian music in the British-based group Indo-Jazz Fusions with the Jamaican-born saxophonist Joe Harriott.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Fox, American activist (b. 1951)

entities.title: Tom Fox (Quaker)
entities.description: Thomas William Fox was an American Quaker peace activist, affiliated with Christian Peacemaker Teams (CPT) in Iraq. He was kidnapped on November 26, 2005 in Baghdad along with three other CPT activists, leading to the 2005-2006 Christian Peacemaker hostage crisis. His body was found on March 9, 2006.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Profumo, English soldier and politician, Secretary of State for War (b. 1915)

entities.title: Secretary of State for War
entities.description: The position of Secretary of State for War, commonly called War Secretary, was a British cabinet-level position which existed from 1794 to 1801 and from 1854 to 1964. The Secretary of State for War headed the War Office and was assisted by a Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for War, a Parliamentary Private Secretary who was also a Member of Parliament, and a Military Secretary, who was a gen

heading: Deaths
txt: Brad Delp, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1951)

entities.title: Brad Delp
entities.description: Bradley Edward Delp was an American singer and songwriter, widely known as the lead vocalist of the rock bands Boston and RTZ.

heading: Deaths
txt: Glen Harmon, Canadian ice hockey player (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Willie Davis, American baseball player and manager (b. 1940)

entities.title: Willie Davis (baseball)
entities.description: William Henry Davis was a center fielder in Major League Baseball who played most of his career for the Los Angeles Dodgers. At the end of his career he ranked seventh in major league history in putouts (5449) and total chances (5719) in the outfield, and third in games in center field (2237). He was ninth in National League history in total outfield games (2274), and won Gold Glove Awards from 19

heading: Deaths
txt: Doris Haddock, American activist and politician (b. 1910)

heading: Deaths
txt: David S. Broder, American journalist and academic (b. 1929)

entities.title: David S. Broder
entities.description: David Salzer Broder, was an American journalist, writing for The Washington Post for over 40 years. He was also an author, television news show pundit, and university lecturer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Max Jakobson, Finnish journalist and diplomat

entities.title: Max Jakobson
entities.description: Max Jakobson was a Finnish diplomat and journalist of Finnish-Jewish descent. Jakobson was an instrumental figure in shaping Finland's policy of neutrality during the Cold War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Merton Simpson, American painter and art collector (b. 1928)

heading: Deaths
txt: James Molyneaux, Baron Molyneaux of Killead, Northern Irish soldier and politician (b. 1920)

entities.title: James Molyneaux, Baron Molyneaux of Killead
entities.description: James Henry Molyneaux, Baron Molyneaux of Killead, KBE, PC, often known as Jim Molyneaux, was a Northern Irish unionist politician, and leader of the Ulster Unionist Party from 1979 to 1995. He was a leading member and sometime Vice-President of the Conservative Monday Club. An Orangeman, he was also Sovereign Grand Master of the Royal Black Institution from 1971 to 1995.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Horton, American actor (b. 1924)

entities.title: Robert Horton (actor)
entities.description: Meade Howard Horton Jr., known as Robert Horton, was an American actor and singer. He is best known as Flint in Wagon Train (1957-1962).

heading: Deaths
txt: Clyde Lovellette, American basketball player and coach (b. 1929)

heading: Deaths
txt: Howard Hodgkin, British painter (b. 1932)

entities.title: Howard Hodgkin
entities.description: Sir Gordon Howard Eliott Hodgkin was a British painter and printmaker. His work is most often associated with abstraction.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jo Min-ki, Korean actor (b. 1965)

entities.title: Jo Min-ki
entities.description: Jo Min-ki was a South Korean actor. He is best known for his roles in the television series Love and Ambition, East of Eden, Queen Seondeok, and Flames of Desire. He was also a noted photographer and published two books and held solo exhibitions,. In addition since 2010 he was an assistant professor at Cheongju University.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Bathersby, Australian Catholic bishop (b. 1936)

entities.title: John Bathersby
entities.description: John Alexius Bathersby was an Australian bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. He was the sixth archbishop of the Archdiocese of Brisbane, serving from 1991 until his retirement in 2011. Bathersby was conferred with the title Emeritus Archbishop of Brisbane.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Levine, American conductor and pianist (b. 1943)

entities.title: James Levine
entities.description: James Lawrence Levine was an American conductor and pianist. He was music director of the Metropolitan Opera from 1976 to 2016. He was formally terminated from all his positions and affiliations with the Met on March 12, 2018, over sexual misconduct allegations, which he denied.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roger Mudd, American journalist (b. 1928)
